[[Image:Live USB ubuntu.png|thumb|280px|right|A live USB of [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], running [[Firefox]], [[OpenOffice.org]] and the [[Nautilus (file manager)|Nautilus file manager]].]]
A '''live USB''' is a [[USB flash drive]] or a USB [[external hard disk drive]] containing a full [[operating system]] which can be [[booting|booted]]. Live USBs are closely related to [[live CD]]s, but sometimes have the ability to persistently save settings and permanently install software packages back onto the USB device. Like live CDs, live USBs can be used in embedded systems for [[system administration]], [[data recovery]], or the testing of operating system distributions without committing to a permanent installation on the local [[hard disk drive]]. Many operating systems including Mac OS 9, Mac OS X, Microsoft [[Windows XP Embedded]] and many of the [[Linux distribution]]s and [[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]]s can also be used from a USB flash drive.
A '''live USB''' is a [[USB flash drive]] or a USB [[external hard disk drive]] containing a full [[operating system]] which can be [[booting|booted]]. Live USBs are closely related to [[live CD]]s, but sometimes have the ability to persistently save settings and permanently install software packages back onto the USB device. Like live CDs, live USBs can be used in embedded systems for [[system administration]], [[data recovery]], or the testing of operating system distributions without committing to a permanent installation on the local [[hard disk drive]]. Many operating systems including Mac OS 9, Mac OS X, Microsoft [[Windows XP Embedded]] and many of the [[Linux distribution]]s and [[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]]s can also be used from a USB flash drive.
